docs.lead_paragraph: PRESSING BUSH ON HEALTH CARE -- The nation's governors urged President Bush to provide more money to help them guarantee health insurance for children. [Page A1.] WHERE HAVE ALL THE BEES GONE? -- Growers who need bees to cross-pollinate their crops are nervous. In some places, there is an explicable shortage of bees to accomplish the job. [A1.] GAP CLOSES A SPECIALTY CHAIN -- Gap is closing its Forth & Towne stores after 18 months of operation. The stores sold clothes intended to appeal to professional women, but those women bought what they wanted at department stores, shunning the saturated specialty store market. [C1.] A BALANCING ACT FOR TXU BIDDERS -- The equity firms offering to buy the TXU Corporation made a pact with environmentalists, but it's unclear that a new company will be able to keep all its constituents happy. [C1.] NEW TWIST IN FINANCING BIG DEALS -- An arrangement known as an equity bridge is helping leveraged buyout firms buy companies with less cash up front. But this tactic can cause problems. [C1.] SOME SKEPTICISM ABOUT CITIGROUP -- Citigroup's appointment of Gary L. Crittenden brings operational expertise and credibility, but a turnaround of the company is sure to take a long time. Market Place. [C1.] HELP WANTED: MINERS -- From the pits of Australia to the coal fields of Wyoming, mining companies are desperately seeking workers to address a dire shortage. [C1.] FOLLOWING ALL THE RULES -- A Web video venture called Joost, started by the founders of the file-sharing site Kazaa and the Internet telephone service Skype, are doing everything by the book this time. Revenue-sharing agreements have been signed and licenses have been granted. [C3.] BIG PLANS FOR CITY TOURISM -- The new head of the city's tourism bureau -- and the first advertising man to hold the job -- is planning to use new strategies to attract 50 million visitors a year to New York City by 2015. [B1.] N.B.A. HAS A DEAL WITH YOUTUBE -- The National Basketball Association, like the National Hockey League, is creating a channel for league video and for viewers to post their best moves. [D2.] NEW CHIEF AT ELECTRONICS ARTS -- Surprising investors, Electronic Arts said its chief executive, Lawrence F. Probst, would step down April 1, ending a 16-year tenure. Mr. Probst will remain as executive chairman. [C2.] CONCERN OVER ANEMIA DRUGS -- New studies are raising questions about whether drugs to fight anemia, which have been used by millions of cancer patients. might actually be harming them. [C3.] MICROSOFT ENTERS HEALTH SEARCH -- Microsoft, preparing to move into the health care market, is buying a specialized search engine tailored to deliver useful medical information to consumers. [C2.] CONFERENCE BOARD CHIEF -- The Conference Board, which publishes some of the nation's leading economic surveys, has selected a new chief executive. [C3.] NEW CHIEF FOR WELLPOINT -- WellPoint, the nation's biggest health insurer, has tapped Angela F. Braly, 45, the company's general counsel and government affairs strategist, to succeed Larry C. Glasscock, 58, left, who will stay on as chairman when the change takes effect on June 1. Mr. Glasscock said he was retiring for family reasons. [C3.] CHANGES AHEAD FOR AIRBUS -- The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of the aircraft maker Airbus, has a turnaround plan for the company that will be announced tomorrow. [C7.] AND THE WINNER WAS -- The 79th Academy Awards beat the Super Bowl in the race for best advertising. The ads on the Oscars were celebratory rather than sour, light-hearted rather than dour. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C6.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE SMITH & WOLLENSKY Restaurant Group said that it would be acquired by a Los Angeles restaurant group for $79.5 million. Its properties in New York, however, will remain in the hands of its founder. (NYT) LYONDELL CHEMICAL said that it had agreed to sell its titanium dioxide pigment business to an affiliate of the National Industrialization Company of Saudi Arabia for about $1.2 billion. (REUTERS) HUB INTERNATIONAL, the insurance broker, said that it would be acquired by the private equity firm Apax Partners and by Morgan Stanley Principal Investments for about $1.7 billion. (REUTERS) XM SATELLITE RADIO HOLDINGS, which announced plans last week to combine with its rival, Sirius Satellite Radio, reported a narrower loss in the fourth quarter. (AP) THE NYSE GROUP said that it appointed Duncan L. Niederauer, a managing director at Goldman Sachs, president and co-chief operating officer effective April 9. (REUTERS) MARVEL ENTERTAINMENT lowered its outlook for 2007, and its shares fell sharply. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Moral Waivers and the Military'' (editorial, Feb. 20): As a member of the Army, I have a vested interest in the quality of the recruits who fill our ranks. I agree that as an institution, we need to do a better job of tracking and following up on the adjustment of many of these soldiers with moral waivers.
docs.abstract: Four letters comment on Feb 20 editorial on US Army's granting of 'moral waivers' to meet enlistment goals due to extended tours of duty in Iraq; Maj Kendric H Robbins says political leaders are responsible for correcting issue, through either additional resources or change in policy; Perry Jefferies says term 'moral waivers' euphemizes real problem, which is that some new soldiers are dangerous criminals; Robert Gaston says he finds granting of these waivers 'astonishing'; Prof Daniel C Maguire says it is pity that US military is 'America's face to much of world'
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Moral Waivers and the Military'' (editorial, Feb. 20):     As a member of the Army, I have a vested interest in the quality of the recruits who fill our ranks. I agree that as an institution, we need to do a better job of...

docs.lead_paragraph: It should come as little surprise that Social Security numbers are posted on the Internet. But, says Betty Ostergren, a former insurance claims supervisor in suburban Richmond, Va., who has spent years trolling for them, ''people are always astounded'' to learn that theirs is one of them. Mrs. Ostergren, 57, has made a name for herself as a gadfly as she took on a lonely and sometimes frustrating mission to draw attention to the situation. With addresses, dates of birth and maiden names often associated with Social Security numbers, she said, they are a gift to data thieves.

headline.main: Your Social Security Number Is a Few Clicks Away

docs.abstract: Article offers advice on how to prevent Social Security numbers from being revealed to would-be data thieves on Internet; Betty Ostergren's Virginia Watchdog and David Bloys' Web site, NewsforPublicOfficials.com highlight public records issue; states and counties have started removing images of documents that contain Social Security numbers or are blocking out numbers; TrustedID has compiled database of compromised numbers and created online search tool, StolenIDSearch.com, where people can check at no cost to see if their number is in too-public domain; photo (M)
